Award.AwardTitle: Conference in Geometry, Analysis, and Probability
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of US participants in the "Conference in Geometry, Analysis, and Probability" that will be held May 8-12, 2017, at the Korea Institute for Advanced Study (KIAS) in Seoul, South Korea. For additional information see the conference website: http://newton.kias.re.kr/~namgyu/index.html/PJ2017/ .

The overarching theme of this conference is the exploration of the relationship between analytic objects (e.g., analytic capacity, harmonic measure) and geometric concepts (e.g., rectifiability, Hausdorff dimension). The long list of speakers includes the names of a host of the world's leading researchers in harmonic analysis, complex analysis, geometric measure theory, and geometric combinatorics. The program provides ample opportunity for early-career mathematicians to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

 

We held a conference in the Korea Institute of Advanced Study (KIAS) during May 8–12, 2017. The topics covered were Geometry, Analysis and Probability. It explored these areas  from the perspectives of both established experts and younger researchers, with an emphasis on interactions between areas and the basic themes that recur in each of them.  Specific topics included recent advances in Harmonic Measure, Singular Integrals Schramm-Loewner Evolutions (SLE), Gaussian Free Fields (GFF), Rectifiability, and the analysis of Big Data. 

The conference included 27 talks (45 minutes each) and a poster session with 11 posters.  The posters were left up for the entire duration of the conference in the common area where people were after lunch.  There was often a lively discussion around them. This provided excellent exposure for the poster presenters, all of which were participants.  The long talks were  given by people at all stages of their careers, ranging from early career participants (such as J. Azzam, A Logunov and S. Steinerberger), to very distinguished participants (such as S. Smirnov) and everything in between.  

Two aspects which made this conference especially successfull were the comfortable interaction between people at different levels of their career  and the interaction between people in different (yet related) fields. Both of these can be attributed to the informal atmosphere and outgoing character of many of the participants.

Funds were used for US mathematicians not otherwise funded fot participation in a conference we were holding.  This included a diverse group of people.

More technical details (including abstracts and videos of all the talks) are on the webpage. http://newton.kias.re.kr/~namgyu/index.html/PJ2017/ 

A program is available at http://newton.kias.re.kr/~namgyu/index.html/PJ2017/booklet.pdf
